pair.t: Children as young as six are being sexually abused by UN peacekeepers and aid workers, says a leading UK charity. Children in post-conflict areas are being abused by the very people drafted into such zones to help look after them, says Save the Children.
pair.h: UN peacekeepers abuse children.

pair.t: Sexual abuse of children as young as six by aid workers and United Nations peacekeepers has continued unchecked despite repeated promises to stamp it out, according to a 12-month investigation.
pair.h: UN peacekeepers abuse children.

pair.t: On July 26, by unanimous vote, the United Nations Security Council passed a resolution that provides concrete proposals to protect children affected by armed conflict.
pair.h: UN peacekeepers abuse children.

pair.t: Save the Children demanded action after its research found that starving and desperate youngsters as young as six were being coerced to sell sex for food, money, soap and even mobile phones in war zones and disaster areas.
pair.h: UN peacekeepers abuse children.

pair.t: By the end of 2002, approximately 300,200 persons were reported as HIV-positive in the 15 countries of the former USSR, with the rate of HIV infection increasing rapidly. Throughout Eastern Europe, the period 2000-01 saw a sharp increase in infections, especially among intravenous drug users.
pair.h: AIDS victims increase in Europe.

pair.t: Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union, which already have the world's fastest-rising rates of new HIV infections, are headed for a large-scale epidemic if programs to combat AIDS do not go into full swing now, warned health officials from the region.
pair.h: AIDS victims increase in Europe.

pair.t: AIDS could cut population numbers in some of the worst-hit African countries - the first falls attributable to disease since bubonic plague ravaged Europe.
pair.h: AIDS victims increase in Europe.

pair.t: Reports from other developed nations were corroborating these findings. Europe, New Zealand and Australia were also beginning to report decreases in new HIV cases.
pair.h: AIDS victims increase in Europe.

pair.t: When the triumphant Roman arrived, she attempted to seduce him, but he resisted her charms. Rather than fall under Octavian's domination, Cleopatra committed suicide on August 30, 30 B.C., possibly by means of an asp, a poisonous Egyptian serpent and symbol of divine royalty.
pair.h: Cleopatra committed suicide.

pair.t: In the end, defeated, Antony committed suicide and so did Cleopatra, according to legend, by putting an asp to her breast.
pair.h: Cleopatra committed suicide.

pair.t: Best known for her liaisons with the two great Roman leaders Julius Caesar and Mark Antony, Cleopatra's life will be plotted in an exhibition which aims to display contemporary and modern attitudes to her.
pair.h: Cleopatra committed suicide.

pair.t: Boris Franz Becker, German tennis player who, on July 7, 1985, became the youngest champion in the history of the men's singles at Wimbledon.
pair.h: Becker was a tennis champion.

pair.t: Boris Franz Becker, born on November 22, 1967 in Leimen, Germany, is a former World No. 1 professional tennis player from Germany and a six-time Grand Slam singles champion, an Olympic gold medalist, the youngest-ever winner of the men's singles title at Wimbledon at the age of 17. Since he retired from the professional sport, media work and colourful aspects of his personal life have kept him in the headlines.
pair.h: Becker was a tennis champion.

pair.t: Set in the New York City borough of The Bronx, the show starred Ted Danson as the title character, Dr. John Becker, a doctor who operates a small practice and is constantly annoyed by his patients, co-workers, friends, and practically everything and everybody else in his world. Becker has never played tennis in his life.
pair.h: Becker was a tennis champion.

pair.t: Boris Becker has told a German court that he made financial mistakes 10 years ago but denied deliberately cheating his taxes.
pair.h: Becker was a tennis champion.

pair.t: A 66-year-old man has been sentenced to life in prison by a French court for murdering seven girls and young women. Michel Fourniret, dubbed the "Ogre of the Ardennes", had admitted kidnapping and killing his victims between 1987 and 2001.
pair.h: Michel Fourniret was sentenced to life imprisonment.

pair.t: A French court on Wednesday sentenced serial killer Michel Fourniret and his wife to life in prison for the murder of seven girls and young women.
pair.h: Michel Fourniret was sentenced to life imprisonment.

pair.t: The victims' families, as well as women who survived Michel Fourniret's alleged attacks, sat opposite the accused and his wife Monique Olivier on the first day of the trial for the kidnap, rape and murder of seven young women and girls.
pair.h: Michel Fourniret was sentenced to life imprisonment.

pair.t: Due to corruption claims, Mr Olmert resigns following Mr Barak's threat to pull Labour from the ruling coalition with Olmert's Kadima party which could set the scene for new elections.
pair.h: Prime Minister Olmert resigns over corruption claims.

pair.t: Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert, responding to fresh accusations that he illegally accepted hundreds of thousands of dollars from a U.S. citizen, on Thursday said he will step down.
pair.h: Prime Minister Olmert resigns over corruption claims.

pair.t: This year the eyes of the world will turn to China as they host the Olympic Games. To celebrate the history and culture of this remarkable country a host of exhibitions and events are being held across the region right throughout the year.
pair.h: China hosts Olympic games.

pair.t: The Dalai Lama today called for Tibetans to end protests against the Beijing Olympics, also telling MPs in London he would happily accept an invitation to attend the event if relations with China improved.
pair.h: China hosts Olympic games.

pair.t: British Prime Minister Gordon Brown has also said he will skip the opening ceremony of the Games. China responded to Mr Rogge's plea by warning the IOC to keep "irrelevant political factors" away from the Games.
pair.h: China hosts Olympic games.

pair.t: A group of senior US Democrats has urged the Bush administration to begin direct talks with North Korea, warning that the secretive state poses a far greater threat of becoming a hostile nuclear power than Iraq.
pair.h: Bush is criticised over Iraq.

pair.t: Former White House spokesman Scott McClellan has said US President George W Bush was not "open and forthright" on Iraq and rushed to an unnecessary war. In a new book, Mr McClellan says Mr Bush relied on a "political propaganda campaign" to sell the war. His handling of Hurricane Katrina is also attacked.
pair.h: Bush is criticised over Iraq.

pair.t: Australia and Japan, two countries that have backed Bush's military intervention in Iraq with their own forces, praised Bush's role on the world stage and his call for freedom to combat tyranny.
pair.h: Bush is criticised over Iraq.

pair.t: Governments across the world - particularly in a belt of countries across North Africa, from Mauritania to Egypt - are looking nervously at rising food prices and wondering about the political impact if things do not ease soon.
pair.h: Food prices are on the increase.

pair.t: Lower food prices pushed the UK's inflation rate down to 1.1% in August, the lowest level since 1963. The headline rate of inflation fell to 1.1% in August, pushed down by falling food prices.
pair.h: Food prices are on the increase.

pair.t: Most of the debate so far on the food crisis has focused on boosting aid to poorer countries, said Jakob Kellenberger, president of the International Committee of the Red Cross. But, he said, "The second dimension is there is also the potential of food-related violence."
pair.h: Food prices are on the increase.

pair.t: US Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice has been defending President Bush's Iraq strategy at a Senate hearing.
pair.h: Rice defends Bush.

pair.t: The US secretary of state, Condoleezza Rice, yesterday defended President George Bush's climate change conference in Washington against accusations that it was a spoiler intended to undermine UN efforts to secure a global compromise.
pair.h: Rice defends Bush.

pair.t: New US Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice says attacking Iran is not on the US agenda "at this point in time".
pair.h: Rice defends Bush.

pair.t: Mr Bush also said US Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice would go to the area. Mr Blair was heard saying Ms Rice had to succeed in the mission.
pair.h: Rice defends Bush.

pair.t: South Korea has lifted a five-year ban on beef imports from the US, despite growing public protests prompted by fears of mad cow disease.
pair.h: South Korea removes a US beef ban.

pair.t: South Korea agreed to resume beef imports from the United States that were halted in 2003 by concerns over mad cow disease. The decision removed a major dispute and shows how eager South Korea's new president, Lee Myung-bak, is to mend ties with Washington.
pair.h: South Korea removes a US beef ban.

pair.t: Other countries outside Europe, including Russia, the US, Japan and South Korea yesterday moved to ban British livestock and unpasteurised milk. The United States and Japan already have bans in place on British beef imports.
pair.h: South Korea removes a US beef ban.

pair.t: Spain appeared hardest hit by the protests today. An estimated 100,000 farmers drove tractors through Madrid and dozens of other Spanish cities, warning of more aggressive action if there is no agreement to compensate them for higher fuel costs by October.
pair.h: Spain stages fuel protests.

pair.t: The protests spreading across Europe signal a growing agitation at skyrocketing fuel prices in nations already accustomed to paying dearly at the pump.
pair.h: Spain stages fuel protests.

pair.t: In Spain, for example, where gasoline costs 1 to 1.25 euros a liter, many consumers are grumbling more about the rise in grocery bills than the price at the pump and no protests will take place over increasing fuel prices.
pair.h: Spain stages fuel protests.

pair.t: Nigeria is in the grips of a power generating crisis that risks strangling the local economy, the Financial Times reports. Power generation in Africa's largest oil producing country has fallen below its present 4,000 megawatts capacity to 800 megawatts in recent weeks.
pair.h: Nigeria power shortage is to persist.

pair.t: IAEA officials say they have never previously seen such widespread interest in starting a domestic nuclear power industry. While officials declined to detail their correspondence with specific countries, the list of the newly interested includes several African countries, such as Nigeria and Namibia, and at least half a dozen former Soviet republics that are embracing new Western designs to replace less-reliable Soviet nuclear plants.
pair.h: Nigeria power shortage is to persist.

pair.t: President Yar'Adua immediately announced an ambitious seven point plan, aimed at tackling the energy crisis, reducing unemployment, investing in agriculture and land reform, fighting crime as well as improving education and public transport. Nowadays, Nigeria enjoys a constant supply of electricity and power shortages are a thing of the past.
pair.h: Nigeria power shortage is to persist.

pair.t: Nigeria is the eighth largest exporter of oil but couldn't generate enough electricity to meet the needs of its 140 million-strong population. But three newly finished gas-fuelled power stations are able to generate all the electricity requirements and are keeping up with the demand.
pair.h: Nigeria power shortage is to persist.

pair.t: Germany's unemployment rate has fallen below 8% for the first time in more than 16 years, government figures show. The number of people out of work in May was 131,000 lower than in the previous month to 3.283 million. The jobless rate was 7.8% - from 8.1% in April.
pair.h: Germany's jobless rate decreases.

pair.t: As German voters go to the polls on Sunday, unemployment will be a key issue. Despite tough labour market reforms, the number of unemployed has risen to 5m. And Germany's jobless are getting despondent.
pair.h: Germany's jobless rate decreases.

pair.t: Indonesia has said it will quit the oil producers' body Opec as it is no longer a net exporter of the commodity. Energy minister Purnomo Yusgiantoro confirmed the move, which had been anticipated for some time.
pair.h: Indonesia leaves OPEC.

pair.t: Purnomo Yusgiantoro, the energy minister and the current president of OPEC, said he was confident Indonesia's status as a net importer was temporary and that it would be a net exporter again by the end of this year.
pair.h: Indonesia leaves OPEC.

pair.t: Indonesia has revisited its OPEC membership, but decided to stay on to maintain high-level relations with big-time oil powers like Saudi Arabia. After all, Indonesia has the world's highest Muslim population, giving it another major tie to Gulf exporters.
pair.h: Indonesia leaves OPEC.

pair.t: Bahrain's king has appointed a Jewish woman as the country's envoy to the United States. Houda Nonoo said she was proud to serve her country "first of all as a Bahraini" and that she was not chosen for the post because of her religion.
pair.h: Bahrain names a Jewish ambassador.

pair.t: Bahrain's King Hamad bin Isa al-Khalifa has issued a royal decree appointing a female Jewish lawmaker to the post of ambassador to Washington. Hoda Nono has served as a legislator in Bahrain's all-appointed 40-member Shura Council for three years. Nono is the first Jew in the Arab world to become an ambassador.
pair.h: Bahrain names a Jewish ambassador.

pair.t: Jews migrated to Bahrain in the 19th century, mostly from Iran and Iraq. Their numbers increased early in the 20th century but decreased after the 1948 Arab-Israeli war, when many left for Israel, the U.S. and Europe. Jews keep a low profile in Bahrain, working mostly in banks, commercial and trade companies and retail. Jews are not allowed to work for the government or to represent the nation.
pair.h: Bahrain names a Jewish ambassador.

pair.t: Europe's human rights commissioner is to write to Gordon Brown this week warning him that the proposal to detain terror suspects for up to 42 days without charge is an "excessive" measure that will put Britain "way out of line" with the rest of Europe and will prove counter-productive.
pair.h: Police can detain terror suspects for 42 days without charge.

pair.t: Gordon Brown today made a defiant stand in defence of his plan to detain terror suspects for up to 42 days without charge, insisting he had balanced the need to protect civil liberties against the interests of national security. Police are allowed to detain terror suspects for 42 days.
pair.h: Police can detain terror suspects for 42 days without charge.

pair.t: Plans to detain terrorist suspects for up to 42 days without charge suffered a fresh setback after the controversial measure was described as unnecessary by the Director of Public Prosecutions. Police will not be allowed to detain terror suspects for more than 28 days.
pair.h: Police can detain terror suspects for 42 days without charge.

pair.t: Losses at UK mortgage lender Bradford & Bingley have sent its shares tumbling as it warns of a tougher climate ahead. It made a £8m pre-tax loss in the first four months of 2008, compared with £108m profits the same time last year.
pair.h: Bradford & Bingley falls into the red.

pair.t: In a bad-tempered outburst last week, Steven Crawshaw, chief executive of Bradford & Bingley, accused analysts of looking for "communists under every bed" when questioned about the bank's £300m rights issue. The normally breezy boss added that, after years of criticism for not being enough like its fast-growing rival from the North East, Northern Rock, now it was being blamed "for the sins of being too much like Northern Rock".
pair.h: Bradford & Bingley falls into the red.

pair.t: Syria has agreed to allow inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency to visit the country this month, where they expect to examine a site destroyed by Israeli warplanes in September last year.
pair.h: Nuclear inspectors are to visit Syria.

pair.t: At least three sites have been identified by U.S. officials and passed along to the International Atomic Energy Agency, which is negotiating with Syria for permission to conduct inspections in the country, according to U.S. government officials and Western diplomats.
pair.h: Nuclear inspectors are to visit Syria.

pair.t: He criticized the United States for not disclosing its intelligence information sooner. Israel should have given IAEA inspectors a chance to investigate any Syrian nuclear activity before bombing the site, he added.
pair.h: Nuclear inspectors are to visit Syria.

pair.t: Syrian officials have said the bombed building was an empty military warehouse. They have refused to let nuclear inspectors visit the location, which was bulldozed after the bombing.
pair.h: Nuclear inspectors are to visit Syria.

pair.t: Fifty one persons were killed today when two trains travelling on the same track collided in northern Egypt in the country's deadliest rail crash in four years. Two carriages were derailed in a tangle of torn metal as one train slammed into the back of another.
pair.h: A French train crash killed children.

pair.t: Five children have been killed after a train collided with a school bus in the French Alps today. The accident occurred in the town of Mesinges when the train, travelling from Annemasse and Thonon-les-Bains, crashed into the bus carrying around 50 children.
pair.h: A French train crash killed children.

pair.t: Police in eastern France say at least five people were killed when a train crashed into a bus carrying schoolchildren. Police in the Haute-Savoie region on the Swiss border says at least 12 people were injured in the crash near the town of Allinges. No children were among the victims.
pair.h: A French train crash killed children.

pair.t: At least five people have been killed in a head-on train collision in north-eastern France, while others are still trapped in the wreckage. All the victims are adults.
pair.h: A French train crash killed children.

pair.t: The United Nations Special Envoy to Somalia, Mr. Ahmedou Ould-Abdallah, has expressed his optimism that UN-backed peace talks between the Somali interim government and its opposition would succeed despite initial setbacks.
pair.h: UN envoys lead Somali peace talks.

pair.t: The faction, the Somali National Alliance of Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, said in a statement that the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, does not understand Somalia's "intricate political problems" and that his approach to peacemaking was "too meddling, too divisive and too secretive to produce any positive result for the betterment of Somalia."
pair.h: UN envoys lead Somali peace talks.

pair.t: Egypt is mediating the face to face talks between Somali's two most powerful warlords, Hussein Mohammed Aidid and Ali Mahdi Mohammed and their respective allies. No UN envoys are present.
pair.h: UN envoys lead Somali peace talks.

pair.t: Two Britons have died in a light aircraft plane crash in north west Italy, the Foreign Office has said.
pair.h: A plane crashes in Italy.

pair.t: An American-owned Boeing 747 cargo plane crashed as it took off at Brussels airport on Sunday but no injuries were reported, an airport spokeswoman told AFP. The plane that was presumed to have crashed in Italy has been found. The report of a crash was a false alarm.
pair.h: A plane crashes in Italy.

pair.t: A judge in Texas has signed an order allowing parents to take home more than 400 children who had been removed from a polygamist sect. Parents were set to begin collecting their children, who were seized from the sect's ranch by state authorities in April.
pair.h: US sect children are sent home.

pair.t: Child welfare workers were struggling Thursday to find foster care facilities for some 437 children removed from a polygamist sect in Texas amid allegations of widespread sexual abuse. The children will not be returned to their families.
pair.h: US sect children are sent home.

pair.t: A key UN-sponsored summit has opened in Rome aimed at addressing the problem of soaring global food prices.
pair.h: UN summit targets global food crisis.

pair.t: World leaders at a U.N. summit have the opportunity to devise a strategy to stop skyrocketing food prices from adding millions more to the multitudes of those across the globe who already lack enough to eat.
pair.h: UN summit targets global food crisis.

pair.t: With tales of rising seas and talk of human solidarity, world leaders at the first United Nations climate summit sought Monday to put new urgency into global talks to reduce global-warming emissions.
pair.h: UN summit targets global food crisis.

pair.t: The 2005 United Nations World Summit, which is drawing to a close in New York today, was the first opportunity for world leaders to review the progress made in the implementation of the Millennium Declaration, including the eight Millennium Development Goals.
pair.h: UN summit targets global food crisis.

pair.t: At the World Summit sustainable development was reaffirmed as a central component of the international agenda. A wide range of targets and concrete commitments for action to implement sustainable development objectives were agreed and reaffirmed by governments. Health (the theme of the first plenary) was identified as one of five priority sectoral issues under the framework of the Water, Energy, Health, Agriculture and Biodiversity (WEHAB) initiative. The current food crisis was ignored.
pair.h: UN summit targets global food crisis.

pair.t: Nigeria's National Drug Law Enforcement Agency (NDLEA) has seized 80 metric tonnes of cannabis in one of its largest ever hauls, officials say.
pair.h: Nigeria seizes 80 tonnes of drugs.

pair.t: Nigerian police have grounded a Virgin Atlantic flight after a crew member was caught with cocaine in his luggage. The plane was due to take off for London Heathrow from Lagos airport when anti-drug agents found 1.7 kg of cocaine concealed in the crewman's bag.
pair.h: Nigeria seizes 80 tonnes of drugs.

pair.t: Nigeria announced last night that it would start providing free anti-retroviral drugs to HIV/Aids patients next month. With about 3.5 million sufferers, Nigeria has the world's third-highest population of people with HIV/Aids after India and South Africa.
pair.h: Nigeria seizes 80 tonnes of drugs.

pair.t: Nigeria's drugs agency seized 80 tonnes of cannabis in its largest ever single haul, in the southwestern city of Ibadan, a senior official said Tuesday. "The seizure was achieved through coordinated efforts of our men and other security agents. Some 80 metric tonnes of cannabis had been loaded in three vehicles before the raid," the official from the NDLEA agency told AFP, requesting anonymity.
pair.h: Nigeria seizes 80 tonnes of drugs.

pair.t: A Nigerian caught smuggling cocaine worth more than £1m into Scotland has been jailed for six years. Egbuta Ibe, 36, had the drugs in the lining of his suitcase when he was caught at Aberdeen Airport.
pair.h: Nigeria seizes 80 tonnes of drugs.

pair.t: The campaign chief for Democratic Party presidential hopeful Hillary Clinton has said she will fight on despite reports she was about to concede. Terry McAuliffe told US media it was untrue that she was set to concede that her rival Barack Obama had enough delegates to win.
pair.h: Clinton wins elections.

pair.t: Clinton starts her second term as the first Democratic president to be re-elected since Franklin Roosevelt in 1936.
pair.h: Clinton wins elections.

pair.t: Barack Obama has declared himself "the Democratic nominee for president of the United States". He was speaking to a cheering crowd on the last day of the primary season, as projections showed he had earned enough delegates to clinch the nomination.
pair.h: Obama claims Democratic victory.

pair.t: Senator Barack Obama claimed the Democratic presidential nomination on Tuesday evening, prevailing through an epic battle with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in a primary campaign that inspired millions of voters from every corner of America to demand change in Washington.
pair.h: Obama claims Democratic victory.

pair.t: Sen Obama was officially campaigning in Montana and neighbouring South Dakota ahead of Tuesday's final two primaries in his five-month battle for the Democratic nomination with Hillary Clinton.
pair.h: Obama claims Democratic victory.

pair.t: Astronomers have sighted the smallest planet yet orbiting a normal star outside the solar system - a distant world just three times the size of our own. Discovering a planet with a similar mass to that of Earth is considered the "holy grail" of research into planets that lie outside our Solar System.
pair.h: The smallest extrasolar planet is found.

pair.t: Astronomers have detected the smallest extrasolar planet yet: a world about seven and a half times as massive as Earth, orbiting a star much like ours. All of the 150 or so exoplanets found orbiting normal stars are larger than Uranus, itself 15 times Earth's mass.
pair.h: The smallest extrasolar planet is found.

pair.t: Unlike the Earth, the planet orbits at a distance of only two million miles from its star, whipping round Gliese 876 in just two days. It is so close that its day-side temperature could reach between 200C and 400C - far too hot for any kind of Earth-like life.
pair.h: The smallest extrasolar planet is found.

pair.t: A month or two ago, the Spitzer Space Telescope obtained the first spectra of the atmospheres of extrasolar planets. These results were for large planets close to their parent stars, and relied on the planets happening to pass behind the star, but nonetheless a start has been made.
pair.h: The smallest extrasolar planet is found.

pair.t: International Space Station astronauts are eagerly awaiting the arrival of shuttle Discovery - it is bringing a new pump to mend their broken toilet. The station's urine collection unit, as opposed to its solid waste unit, has been malfunctioning for several days.
pair.h: The space station has toilet trouble.

pair.t: The space station crew has been forced to flush manually with extra water several times a day, ever since the toilet broke two weeks ago. The problem is confined to the urine side of the commode.
pair.h: The space station has toilet trouble.

pair.t: It is possibly the last place you'd want to get caught short - 220 miles above the Earth, travelling at 17,500 mph and with no gravity. But that's the situation confronting astronauts aboard the International Space Station after its only toilet broke, leaving the crew facing a variety of makeshift solutions.
pair.h: The space station has toilet trouble.

pair.t: A team of astronauts have attached a $1bn (£500m) Japanese laboratory to the International Space Station (ISS). The 16-tonne Kibo lab was delivered by the shuttle Discovery. It will be the station's biggest room, for the study of biomedicine and material sciences.
pair.h: The space station has toilet trouble.

pair.t: The European Space Agency's (Esa) station programme manager, Alan Thirkettle, said it was a great engineering achievement. The toilet on the International Space Station is working perfectly.
pair.h: The space station has toilet trouble.

pair.t: Privacy groups are accusing Google of violating California law in its reluctance to provide a direct link to its privacy policy on its homepage. The search engine giant is being asked to write the word "privacy" alongside other information links.
pair.h: Google is accused over a privacy law.

pair.t: Google, the world's biggest search engine, is to face a court case over allegations it is promoting deceptive business practices. Brought by Australia's competition watchdog, it is thought to be the first trading standards lawsuit against the firm, which is facing a string of other legal actions around the world.
pair.h: Google is accused over a privacy law.

pair.t: As Privacy International prepares to publish the first privacy ranking of major Internet companies, Google has embarked on a smear campaign within the media to discredit both PI and the report. The report ranks the privacy performance of the top Internet service companies. Privacy International will then publish a detailed open letter to Google and a demand for an apology.
pair.h: Google is accused over a privacy law.

pair.t: Police in Zimbabwe detained US and UK diplomats for several hours as they investigated political violence there, US ambassador James McGee has said. Mr McGee told the BBC there had earlier been a bid to force their convoy off the road in the town of Bindura when they refused to go to a police station.
pair.h: Diplomats were detained in Zimbabwe.

pair.t: British and American diplomats were today attacked as they tried to investigate political violence in Zimbabwe, the US Embassy in Harare has said.
pair.h: Diplomats were detained in Zimbabwe.

pair.t: US ambassador to Zimbabwe James McGee says police attacked two US vehicles and one vehicle from Britain and detained the diplomats in them. Speaking to CNN by phone from Harare, McGee said, "My people were stopped, detained."
pair.h: Diplomats were detained in Zimbabwe.

pair.t: Workers are battling to dissolve an oil spill heading towards the coast of Argentina after two ships collided off the coast of neighbouring Uruguay. The spill, reported to be 20km (12 miles) long, is being blown towards the Argentine capital, Buenos Aires.
pair.h: An oil spill threatens Buenos Aires.

pair.t: Environmental workers are battling to dissolve a large oil slick which is heading towards the coast of Argentina, after two merchant ships collided off neighbouring Uruguay. The 20 kilometre-long slick is being blown towards the Argentine capital Buenos Aires.
pair.h: An oil spill threatens Buenos Aires.

pair.t: Oil leaking from the MS Explorer cruise ship, which sank in Antarctic waters, could cause an environmental disaster near the Antarctic shore, a top-level Argentine foreign ministry official said on Thursday.
pair.h: An oil spill threatens Buenos Aires.

pair.t: The leader of Conservative MEPs has admitted he broke rules while spending staff allowances worth £160,000 a year, describing the error as a "whoops-a-daisy". Giles Chichester offered a "mea culpa" for making payments to his family company, where he is a paid director, and claimed he did not know about 2003 rule changes tightening up Parliament's financial regulations.
pair.h: Giles Chichester is the leader of the Tories MEPs.

pair.t: A Conservative MEP had his party membership suspended yesterday by the head of the British Tory delegation in the European Parliament after an angry debate about excessive European Union secrecy.
pair.h: Giles Chichester is the leader of the Tories MEPs.

pair.t: Giles Chichester's position was viewed as untenable partly because he had been given the job of a sleazebuster by Mr Cameron to ensure the integrity of Tory MEP expenses. He is not the leader of the Tory MEPs.
pair.h: Giles Chichester is the leader of the Tories MEPs.

pair.t: The European Union should move towards forming a common army, Germany's Angela Merkel said in an interview focusing on the chancellor's vision for the future of the bloc. Just ahead of weekend celebrations marking the 50th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome, the foundations of the European Union, Chancellor Merkel said she envisioned a single European army for the future of the 27-member bloc in the next decades.
pair.h: Germany proposes a common EU army.

pair.t: The issue is sensitive in Germany, where the government remains fiercely opposed to any idea of a "European army". During a visit to London last week, Sarkozy made no public mention of a long-standing French wish for the EU to boost its military planning apparatus. Britain has been wary of anything that would resemble a full-blown EU defence headquarters.
pair.h: Germany proposes a common EU army.

pair.t: Cristiano Ronaldo's future at Manchester United has taken a new twist after the winger was reported as saying he would like to play for Real Madrid. Real have been tracking Ronaldo, 23, despite being warned off by United manager Sir Alex Ferguson.
pair.h: Ronaldo plays for Manchester United.

pair.t: Manchester United could be on course for a bitter summer struggle to retain Cristiano Ronaldo after the player was reported to have said yesterday that he wanted to join Real Madrid.
pair.h: Ronaldo plays for Manchester United.

pair.t: The 23-year-old Portugal international - who last week was named the Professional Footballers' Association Player of the Year - topped the poll of journalists ahead of Liverpool striker Fernando Torres and Portsmouth goalkeeper David James. It is the second season in succession Ronaldo has received the accolade, now in its 61st year.
pair.h: Ronaldo plays for Manchester United.

pair.t: Democratic hopeful Barack Obama has had an unannounced meeting with his defeated rival Hillary Clinton. The talks came two days after Mr Obama effectively clinched the nomination for November's US presidential election.
pair.h: Obama holds talks with Clinton.

pair.t: After a day spent campaigning across Virginia, Obama delayed a trip home to Chicago last night to visit Clinton at the Washington home of Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.), a senior Democratic source said. A joint statement issued by the campaign said: "Senator Clinton and Senator Obama met tonight and had a productive discussion about the important work that needs to be done to succeed in November."
pair.h: Obama holds talks with Clinton.

pair.t: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton will endorse Senator Barack Obama on Saturday, bringing a close to her 17-month campaign for the White House, aides said. Her decision came after Democrats urged her Wednesday to leave the race and allow the party to coalesce around Mr. Obama.
pair.h: Obama holds talks with Clinton.

pair.t: Resisting a defiant push by Hillary Clinton to force him to name her as his running mate, Barack Obama has appeared publicly with three other prominent vice-presidential contenders.
pair.h: Obama holds talks with Clinton.

pair.t: A brilliant rivalry was renewed Thursday night, with all the attendant tension, drama, ill will and ear-splitting volume. And at the end of a long evening of "Beat L.A." chants, the Boston Celtics had their first finals victory in 21 years, a convincing 98-88 defeat of the Lakers at TD Banknorth Garden to open this best-of-seven series.
pair.h: The Boston Celtics defeat the Lakers.

pair.t: Clashing in the finals for the 11th time, the Boston Celtics and the Lakers had not played for the title since 1987 but it quickly became clear that none of the magic and intensity had been lost over the years.
pair.h: The Boston Celtics defeat the Lakers.

pair.t: Arnold 'Red' Auerbach, the legendary coach who guided the Boston Celtics to a record eight straight NBA championships, has died aged 89. A mercurial leader with a shrewd eye for talent, Auerbach was enshrined in the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1969 and captured nine NBA titles overall. Only current Los Angeles Lakers coach Phil Jackson has won as many titles.
pair.h: The Boston Celtics defeat the Lakers.

pair.t: Prime Minister Gordon Brown on Thursday announced a crackdown on teenagers carrying knives, saying that those as young as 16 will be prosecuted for knife possession on the first offense. Previously, in the UK, anyone younger than 18 generally received only a warning.
pair.h: Gordon Brown is the UK Prime Minister.

pair.t: Gordon Brown became Britain's prime minister on June 27, 2007, finally succeeding Tony Blair after serving as heir apparent for over a decade - a wait that Mr. Brown in recent years clearly considered interminable. As chancellor of the Exchequer, the equivalent of the American treasury department, Mr. Brown presided over an unusually prosperous period for Britain of low inflation, low interest rates and low unemployment.
pair.h: Gordon Brown is the UK Prime Minister.

pair.t: Mr Brown's courage and determination are not in doubt: he soaks up punishment as if he believes it is good for him. But week after week he gives no sign that he knows how to seize the initiative and dictate the course of the fight.
pair.h: Gordon Brown is the UK Prime Minister.

pair.t: When Chancellor Gordon Brown and his charismatic boss Tony Blair arrived in Downing Street in 1997, the contrast between them was marked.
pair.h: Gordon Brown is the UK Prime Minister.

pair.t: Group of Eight energy ministers on Sunday looked inward for solutions to oil's unrelenting rally, touting the need for domestic efficiency rather than piling pressure on a resistant OPEC to pump more crude oil.
pair.h: The G8 are meeting to discuss the oil crisis.

pair.t: The Group of Eight (G8) organisation is meeting two days after a record one-day jump in crude oil to $139 a barrel. Efficiency, shared technology and the promotion of alternative power sources will be high on the agenda.
pair.h: The G8 is meeting to discuss the oil crisis.

pair.t: G8 officials will need to hammer out ideas to encourage consumer countries to curb demand as well as enhance agricultural and energy productivity, Fukushiro Nukaga said in a speech at the Foreign Correspondents' Club of Japan.
pair.h: The G8 is meeting to discuss the oil crisis.

pair.t: Japan's Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry, Akira Amari speaks during the press conference of the G8 plus China, India, South Korea Energy Ministerial Meeting in Aomori, northern Japan, on Sunday, June 8, 2008.
pair.h: The G8 is meeting to discuss the oil crisis.

pair.t: The G8 summit is a rare opportunity for the leaders of some of the world's richest countries to come together, face to face, to thrash out issues that affect them all. This year the main issue will be the food crisis. No mention will be made of the current oil problems.
pair.h: The G8 is meeting to discuss the oil crisis.

pair.t: The Bank of England is set to name its chief economist Charles Bean as the new deputy governor, a report suggests. Mr Bean - who is believed to be the first choice of governor Mervyn King - will replace Rachel Lomax, the Sunday Times said.
pair.h: Mr Bean will be the deputy governor of the Bank of England.

pair.t: Again, the City's preference is clear: Tucker, the markets professional, is the man for the post of deputy governor of the Bank of England. At a time when Nationwide tells us that house prices are falling at a record pace, the banks want to know their cries of pain will be heard. Mr Bean has been discarded as a candidate for the job.
pair.h: Mr Bean will be the deputy governor of the Bank of England.

pair.t: Charles Bean, chief economist at the Bank of England, said: "The 64,000 dollar question is whether this (adjustment) happens in a relatively smooth fashion."
pair.h: Mr Bean will be the deputy governor of the Bank of England.

pair.t: The cause was heart failure, a spokeswoman, Susan Clary, said. Mr. Diddley had a heart attack last August, only months after suffering a stroke while touring in Iowa.
pair.h: Bo Diddley died of a heart attack.

pair.t: Bo Diddley, who was 79, died at his home in Florida overnight. The legendary singer and songwriter transformed rhythm and blues to rock and roll in the 1950s with a new hard-edged guitar sound as well as a driving beat behind it.
pair.h: Bo Diddley died of a heart attack.

pair.t: A magnitude 6.5 earthquake has rocked southern Greece, collapsing buildings and causing panic among villagers in the Peloponnese region.
pair.h: An earthquake hit southern Greece.

pair.t: In a rare experiment in "earthquake diplomacy", previously tested successfully between Greece and Turkey, the arrival of an American emergency medical team in Iran is being heralded as a breakthrough in one of the world's longest-running feuds.
pair.h: An earthquake hit southern Greece.

pair.t: Large numbers of farm animals including the majority of the UK's Christmas turkeys, are being fattened in cruel conditions, new research shows. Compassion in World Farming says more than 80% of turkeys sold this year by Asda, Sainsbury's and Morrisons will have been intensively reared.
pair.h: Turkeys are reared cruelly.

pair.t: But Americans consume vastly more chicken, turkey, pork and beef than foie gras and veal, and most of the creatures those meats come from are raised in ways that are ethically and environmentally unsound.
pair.h: Turkeys are reared cruelly.

pair.t: Most people in the UK will be tucking into Christmas turkeys that have been brought up in cramped conditions. An animal welfare charity says that four out of five turkeys sold in major supermarkets have been fattened up in "cruel" factory farms.
pair.h: Turkeys are reared cruelly.

pair.t: Turkey has been the staple of many Thanksgiving dinners over the years. Nowadays, turkeys are pasture-raised and reared on a free-range. These fowls have had access to the outdoors and have been given the freedom to roam as far as possible without flying too high. They have been treated humanely and not cruelly.
pair.h: Turkeys are reared cruelly.

pair.t: Whether it's brined, broiled, baked or served up smoked from the barbecue grill, come the fourth Thursday of November, turkey will be the centerpiece of most Americans' Thanksgiving feast. Yet the thousands of birds available at grocery stores have drifted ever further from the fresh fowl of our forefathers.
pair.h: Turkeys are reared cruelly.

pair.t: Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez has called on Colombia's FARC rebels to end their four-decade struggle and release all their hostages. Mr Chavez, whom Colombia has accused of financing the FARC, said they were "out of step" and their war was "history".
pair.h: FARC rebels are holding hostages.

pair.t: The location of Raul Reyes, deputy commander of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC), was pinpointed just inside Ecuador after Colombian hostage negotiators deliberately intensified talks over the release of captives to force him either to authorise, or to stop, the next stage.
pair.h: FARC rebels are holding hostages.

pair.t: The South Korean government is sending delegates to the US for talks on a controversial beef deal that has triggered weeks of protests. The envoys will meet US officials to discuss changes to the April deal, under which South Korea agreed to resume US beef imports.
pair.h: South Korea is sending beef envoys to the US.

pair.t: U.S. Ambassador to Korea Alexander Vershbow on Tuesday rejected calls to renegotiate a deal to reopen the Korean market to American beef amid huge daily protests against the deal here.
pair.h: South Korea is sending beef envoys to the US.

pair.t: President Lee Myung-bak suggested Tuesday that South Korea will seek to ban imports of U.S. beef from older cattle amid a public backlash against his government over fears of mad cow disease.
pair.h: South Korea is sending beef envoys to the US.

pair.t: The South Korean government said it was delaying the planned resumption of beef imports from the United States after a request from the ruling party and large weekend street protests. All diplomatic relations between S Korea and the US have ceased and no envoys will be sent.
pair.h: South Korea is sending beef envoys to the US.

pair.t: Since the age of 14, 19-year-old Ashleigh has exhibited a very strange allergy. Whenever she comes in contact with water, she feels pain throughout her body.
pair.h: A teenage girl is allergic to water.

pair.t: Now she always keeps umbrellas handy, sleeps with a sheet between her boyfriend Adam to avoid sweat - and stays in for hours after showers to let her rash calm.
pair.h: A teenage girl is allergic to water.

pair.t: When Ashleigh gets wet her body explodes in sore, itchy red lumps that take about two hours to ease. She has to wash. But showering is a painful experience and she can only do it for a minute at a time. These brief showers are the only contact Ashleigh has with water. The one thing she doesn't miss is the washing up.
pair.h: A teenage girl is allergic to water.

pair.t: A German citizen has gone to court in an attempt to force his government to seek the extradition of 13 suspected CIA agents who allegedly kidnapped him.
pair.h: A German citizen is suing for CIA extradition.

pair.t: Herr Steinmeier said that he and other members of the former government under Gerhard Schröder had faced "irresponsible speculation and suspicions" relating to the kidnapping of Khaled al-Masri, a Lebanese-born German suing the CIA for holding him in an Afghan jail for five months.
pair.h: A German citizen is suing for CIA extradition.

pair.t: A German court on Wednesday issued an arrest warrant for 13 people in the mistaken kidnapping and jailing of a German citizen of Lebanese descent, in the most serious legal challenge yet to the Central Intelligence Agency's secret transfers of terrorism suspects.
pair.h: A German citizen is suing for CIA extradition.

pair.t: Some German security officials had opposed the extradition request, arguing that it could undermine U.S.-German cooperation against terrorism. The German victim will not sue for extradition. In a compromise, German officials sent an informal inquiry to Washington last month. When U.S. officials responded that they would not cooperate, German authorities agreed to drop the matter.
pair.h: A German citizen is suing for CIA extradition.

pair.t: Apple is expected to unveil the second generation of its iPhone device at a conference in San Francisco. The firm's chief executive Steve Jobs is being widely tipped to launch the newly designed iPhone, in an effort to boost sales.
pair.h: Apple will issue a new iPhone.

pair.t: Like the iPhone, Samsung's Omnia aims to make Internet browsing easy, and has a wide screen for viewing video as well as music capabilities and a 5 megapixel camera. It runs on Microsoft Windows Mobile software. Apple does not intend to release a new iPhone model.
pair.h: Apple will issue a new iPhone.

pair.t: Romania got what it came for and France got what it deserved as the two teams drew, 0-0, in an utterly sterile opening game Tuesday in Group C of Euro 2008.
pair.h: Romania draws with France.

pair.t: Romania's conservative approach against World Cup finalist France worked Monday in a 0-0 draw in Group C, considered the toughest in the European Championship.
pair.h: Romania draws with France.

pair.t: France dominated possession but did precious little with it. There was no hustle to their laboured attacks and Romania, who were stingy at the back in qualifying as well, coped comfortably.
pair.h: Romania draws with France.

pair.t: Romania, beaten by France in their opening match, was able to stifle a largely muted Gallic attack to emerge with only one goal difference; a priceless point in their fight to survive the group of death that includes world champion Italy and Euro 1988 winner Holland.
pair.h: Romania draws with France.

pair.t: On Sunday, Los Angeles police arrested the star Warren G, real name Warren Griffin III, after finding marijuana in the car he was travelling in.
pair.h: Warren G was arrested for drug possession.

pair.t: Prosecutors said Monday they won't pursue charges against rapper Warren G, who was arrested a day earlier for being in a car with marijuana.
pair.h: Warren G was arrested for drug possession.

pair.t: The "Regulate" hitmaker, real name Warren Griffin III, and his friend Ryan Butler were pulled over by cops in Hollywood in the early hours of Sunday after they ran a red light.
pair.h: Warren G was arrested for drug possession.

pair.t: Attempts to reach Griffin or a representative Sunday night were unsuccessful. Warren G was nominated for a Grammy in 1995. He was arrested in 1996 for carrying a loaded assault weapon in his truck.
pair.h: Warren G was arrested for drug possession.

pair.t: The 37-year-old "Regulate" artist Warren G and friend Ryan Butler were pulled over early Saturday morning for running a red light. The driver, Ryan, was arrested after officers found a large quantity of marijuana in his vehicle; apparently he had intended to sell the narcotics. Warren was not arrested.
pair.h: Warren G was arrested for drug possession.

pair.t: Chart-topping R&B star R. Kelly was arrested in Florida Wednesday, hours after he was indicted on 21 counts of child pornography stemming from a videotape that allegedly shows him having sex with an underage girl, officials said.
pair.h: R. Kelly was convicted for child pornography.

pair.t: R. Kelly was convicted of child pornography after an FBI forensic video expert dismissed claims that a tape at the centre of the R Kelly trial could have been faked using special effects. George Skaluae said he had examined the film and found it to show "real people in a real environment."
pair.h: R. Kelly was convicted for child pornography.

pair.t: R. Kelly was acquitted of child pornography after the star witness Van Allen was discredited after admitting she once stole Kelly's $20,000 diamond-studded watch from a hotel.
pair.h: R. Kelly was convicted for child pornography.

pair.t: The EU and the US have threatened Iran with further sanctions unless it verifiably suspends nuclear enrichment. The measures were announced after US President George W Bush held talks in Slovenia, during what is expected to be his last official tour of Europe.
pair.h: Iran is threatened with more sanctions.

pair.t: Putin said the standoff around Iran's nuclear program needs to be resolved through talks, pointing at North Korea as an example. "Not long ago it didn't seem possible to resolve the situation with North Korea peacefully," but the dispute has been solved, he said.
pair.h: Iran is threatened with more sanctions.

pair.t: The United Nations Security Council has unanimously voted not to impose more sanctions against Iran over its failure to halt uranium enrichment. Instead, an economic package is being offered to try to entice Iran away from nuclear weapons development.
pair.h: Iran is threatened with more sanctions.

pair.t: England cricketers will consider boycotting matches against Zimbabwe next year if President Robert Mugabe is still in power, batsman Andrew Strauss said on Tuesday.
pair.h: England cricketers may boycott Zimbabwe.

pair.t: Australia leg-spinner Stuart MacGill has refused to take part in the upcoming tour of Zimbabwe on moral and ethical grounds. MacGill told Australia's selectors he had made himself unavailable for the tour because he "did not believe he could tour Zimbabwe and maintain a clear conscience."
pair.h: England cricketers may boycott Zimbabwe.

pair.t: Bradford Bulls back-row forward Glenn Morrison will miss the rest of the season with a serious knee injury. A specialist confirmed that the Australian had both torn a muscle and broken part of his kneecap during the 30-14 defeat by Leeds Rhinos in May.
pair.h: Bradford will lose Morrison for the season.

pair.t: Bradford Bulls produced a performance packed full of panache, pace, power and polish to complete an emphatic six-try victory over Huddersfield Giants which suggests they are primed and ready to offer the biggest challenge to Super League champions Leeds.
pair.h: Bradford will lose Morrison for the season.

pair.t: Bradford backrower Glenn Morrison has been ruled out for the rest of the season with a serious knee injury. The Australian missed the Bulls' last two matches with what was thought to be a corked thigh sustained in last month's defeat by Leeds.
pair.h: Bradford will lose Morrison for the season.

pair.t: Glenn Morrison hopes to finish his career with Bradford Bulls after signing up for another year at Odsal. The Australian loose forward's current deal was due to expire at the end of the season but he has agreed to a new contract which will run for at least another 12 months.
pair.h: Bradford will lose Morrison for the season.

pair.t: Corn prices have hit new highs after the US Department of Agriculture forecast that output would fall because of poor weather. Corn hit a record price of $6.672 a bushel for July delivery on the Chicago Board of Trade after the government cut its forecasts for the 2008 yield by 3%.
pair.h: Corn prices increase.

pair.t: The continuing surge in the price of corn, which is punishing households with higher food prices, is cutting the profits of American ethanol producers and playing havoc with an industry that was blamed for causing the grain shortage.
pair.h: Corn prices increase.

pair.t: Those expecting higher beef and pork prices aren't ready to say by how much. Mark Schultz, chief analyst at Northstar Commodity Investment in Minneapolis, predicted that beef prices will rise substantially. (For the latest commodity prices, go here.)
pair.h: Corn prices increase.

pair.t: UK motorists travelling in Europe will find the cheapest fuel in Spain and Switzerland, according to a survey. Switzerland was the only one of 12 European destinations where unleaded fuel cost less than £1 a litre, Post Office Travel Services has claimed.
pair.h: Unleaded fuel costs less in Switzerland.

pair.t: Pump prices have dropped in Spain cutting the cost of fuel by 9p per litre, making it a close runner up to Switzerland and the cheapest of seven euro zone motoring holiday destinations surveyed. At 78p per litre, unleaded petrol costs 24p less in Spain than in the Netherlands, the most expensive of the euro destinations.
pair.h: Unleaded fuel costs less in Switzerland.

pair.t: It is an everyday lottery when it comes to fuel prices at German gas stations. Prices for regular unleaded and diesel gas bounces up and down, often changing twice on the same day. And drivers in this car-loving nation are unhappily dealing with increasing prices at the pump.
pair.h: Unleaded fuel costs less in Switzerland.

pair.t: The price of a liter of gas climbed above 1.40 euros ($1.73 per liter or $6.70 per gallon) in Germany and hit a record high in Switzerland. Spaniards were paying 1.07 euros per liter ($5.08 per gallon) on Friday, up nearly 7 percent since last week.
pair.h: Unleaded fuel costs less in Switzerland.

pair.t: The cost of a litre of petrol at the pump has climbed to record levels in Switzerland as the oil market reacts to uncertainty over the situation in the Middle East. This makes Swiss fuel the most expensive in Europe.
pair.h: Unleaded fuel costs less in Switzerland.

pair.t: Voters in Ireland have rejected the European Union's Lisbon reform treaty in a referendum by 53.4% to 46.6%.
pair.h: Ireland rejects the treaty.

pair.t: Irish voters have rejected the European Union's Lisbon treaty in a referendum, the government acknowledged on Friday, potentially scuppering EU reform plans.
pair.h: Ireland rejects the treaty.

pair.t: Anti-treaty groups from the far left and right mobilized "no" voters by claiming that the treaty would empower EU chiefs in Brussels, Belgium, to force Ireland to change core policies - including its low business tax rates, its military neutrality and its ban on abortion.
pair.h: Ireland rejects the treaty.

pair.t: The Irish Cabinet has approved the Lisbon Treaty, which it says guarantees the Constitutional bar on Irish troops joining a European Union army. Taoiseach Bertie Ahern said the referendum would likely be held in June.
pair.h: Ireland rejects the treaty.

pair.t: At least four people have been killed and about 60 hurt by a 7.2-magnitude earthquake which struck the north of Japan's main island.
pair.h: An earthquake strikes Japan.

pair.t: A strong earthquake struck off the southern tip of Taiwan at 12:26 UTC, triggering a warning from Japan's Meteorological Agency that a 3.3 foot tsunami could be heading towards Basco, in the Philippines.
pair.h: An earthquake strikes Japan.

pair.t: A strong earthquake off Taiwan's southern coast damaged undersea cables, cutting off phone and Internet service Wednesday to parts of China, South Korea, Japan, Southeast Asia and the United States, companies said. The earthquake's effects did not reach Japan.
pair.h: An earthquake strikes Japan.

pair.t: Japan announced Friday it would lift some of its sanctions against North Korea after the communist nation agreed to open a new probe in a long-running row over its abduction of Japanese nationals.
pair.h: Japan lifts sanctions against North Korea.

pair.t: The deal, reached in two days of talks in Beijing, won a reversal of North Korea's long-standing position that its kidnappings of Japanese during the 1970s and '80s were already resolved. Tokyo has long demanded a full investigation into what it says are unsolved cases.
pair.h: Japan lifts sanctions against North Korea.

pair.t: Japan has moved to impose additional economic sanctions against North Korea in response to its claimed nuclear test earlier this week. The new measures amount to a ban on all trade between Japan and the impoverished communist state. The security council of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe decided to enact new sanctions against North Korea.
pair.h: Japan lifts sanctions against North Korea.

pair.t: Deep sea divers have found the wreck of a Royal Navy warship which sank during the American Revolution. The discovery of HMS Ontario, at the bottom of one of the Great Lakes on the US-Canada border, has been hailed an "archaeological miracle".
pair.h: Divers find a warship.

pair.t: After the ship disappeared, the British conducted a sweeping search but tried to keep the sinking secret from Gen. George Washington's troops because of the blow to the British defenses. Hatchway gratings, the binnacle, compasses and several hats and blankets drifted ashore the next day.
pair.h: Divers find a warship.

pair.t: Experts found a tiny gold combined toothpick and earwax spoon, believed to be more than 385 years old, during the search for a shipwrecked Spanish galleon off the Florida Keys.
pair.h: Divers find a warship.

pair.t: Using a mobile phone frequently may be associated with teenage stress, a study has found. It could also be linked to restlessness and sleep-related problems, according to researchers at the Sahlgren Academy in Sweden.
pair.h: Teenage stress is linked to mobile phones.

pair.t: The scientists found that the teenagers who used their mobile phones often were more restless than infrequent users. They also had more "careless" lifestyles, consumed more stimulating beverages, suffered from disrupted sleep or insomnia, and were more susceptible to stress and fatigue.
pair.h: Teenage stress is linked to mobile phones.

pair.t: Researchers in Sweden took a group of young people aged between 14 and 20 and split them into two groups according to their mobile phone use.
pair.h: Teenage stress is linked to mobile phones.

pair.t: Two Spanish children are being treated for addiction to mobile phones, in what is thought to be first case of its kind in the country. The children, 12 and 13, were admitted to a mental health clinic by their parents because they could not carry out normal activities without their phones.
pair.h: Teenage stress is linked to mobile phones.

pair.t: Coldplay singer Chris Martin has walked out of an interview on BBC Radio 4's Front Row, while promoting the band's new album. Drummer Will Champion was left to answer questions from presenter John Wilson until Martin returned for one final question.
pair.h: Chris Martin abandons an interview.

pair.t: Chris Martin, the frontman of the band Coldplay, has left the BBC studios during an interview to promote the band's new album because he was not "really enjoying" himself.
pair.h: Chris Martin abandons an interview.

pair.t: Lead singer Chris Martin and drummer Will Champion were doing a pre-recorded interview with the BBC's Radio 4 arts show Front Row, when after a short 9 minutes he said he was not enjoying his time in the studio. However, he stayed on for the whole interview.
pair.h: Chris Martin abandons an interview.

pair.t: Wrapping up their U.S. tour and preparing for a string of dates abroad, Coldplay frontman Chris Martin and guitarist Jonny Buckland dropped by the Rolling Stone office in New York to field a barrage of random questions from the staff.
pair.h: Chris Martin abandons an interview.

pair.t: Hundreds of environmental protesters have pedalled naked on bikes through Brighton to promote the environmental benefits of cycling. About 500 cyclists stripped off, many adorned only with body paint slogans, for the third annual World Naked Bike Ride held in the Sussex city.
pair.h: Protesters ride naked in Brighton.

pair.t: Five hundred cyclists stripped off today in Brighton for the third annual World Naked Bike Ride. The riders were campaigning against cars and their damage to the environment, many using their bodies a display for slogans.
pair.h: Protesters ride naked in Brighton.

pair.t: Duncan Blinkhorn, 45, one of the organisers, said: "This is a fun if outrageous way to make the serious point that we should not have to tolerate roads, cities and a planet dominated by the brutishness of cars that routinely foul the air we all breathe, destroy lives and impoverish the environment."
pair.h: Protesters ride naked in Brighton.

pair.t: Riding under the slogan "real rights for bikes", participants cycle naked to highlight their vulnerability on city streets and draw attention to the destructive effects of car culture. The ride is a body-positive event where nudity is optional - riders are encouraged to go "as bare as you dare".
pair.h: Protesters ride naked in Brighton.

pair.t: A group of mothers held in the Yarl's Wood immigration centre have staged protests over the extended detention of children. They argue that locking up minors is cruel and say being kept in close confinement has caused outbreaks of viruses.
pair.h: Protesters ride naked in Brighton.

pair.t: Saudi Arabia, the world's biggest oil exporter, is planning to increase its output next month by about a half-million barrels a day, according to analysts and oil traders who have been briefed by Saudi officials. The increase could bring Saudi output to a production level of 10 million barrels a day, which, if sustained, would be the kingdom's highest ever.
pair.h: Saudis raise their oil output.

pair.t: Saudi Arabia has rejected an appeal by US President George W Bush to raise oil production, a US official has said.
pair.h: Saudis raise their oil output.

pair.t: The oil market is "well supplied,'' and prices are being driven by "speculative flows'' and not supply and demand, Shahristani said today in an interview in Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt, at the annual World Economic Forum.
pair.h: Saudis raise their oil output.

pair.t: The only hope for meeting growing world demand for oil is to tap Saudi Arabia's reserves. A Bush advisor on energy says those reserves don't exist.
pair.h: Saudis raise their oil output.

pair.t: George Bush, the US President, has arrived in the UK as his swan song tour of Europe before leaving office draws to a close.
pair.h: Bush visits the UK.

pair.t: President George W. Bush said British Prime Minister Gordon Brown should only withdraw forces from Iraq based on conditions on the ground and not an arbitrary timetable.
pair.h: Bush visits the UK.

pair.t: More than two hundred thousand people gathered Saturday under a downpour on Kiev's Independence Square, the high place of Ukraine's "orange revolution", to hear a free concert by ex-Beatle Sir Paul McCartney.
pair.h: McCartney performs in Kiev.

pair.t: The outdoor show, the first in Ukraine for the former Beatle, was billed as the biggest concert ever in the former Soviet republic. It was broadcast live on national television and on giant screens in five cities.
pair.h: McCartney performs in Kiev.

pair.t: Sir Paul McCartney braved thunder, lightning and torrential rain to perform his first concert in the Ukraine. The ex-Beatle played to an audience of tens of thousands in the capital Kiev's main square last night.
pair.h: McCartney performs in Kiev.

pair.t: Coldplay have shot straight to the top of the UK albums chart - despite their record having been on sale for just three days.
pair.h: Coldplay album tops the UK chart.

pair.t: Coldplay's new album Viva La Vida, Or Death And All His Friends is set to become one of the fastest-selling records in chart history after 125,000 copies were sold in its first day.
pair.h: Coldplay album tops the UK chart.

pair.t: Through Friday, the ring tone "Crazy Frog Axel F," the first tune created for mobile phones to cross into mainstream music charts, was outselling the new single of the group Coldplay by about four to one, the Official UK Charts Company said. The ring tone has robbed the Coldplay album of the possibility of reaching #1 position.
pair.h: Coldplay album tops the UK chart.

pair.t: The show can also give Americans an early look at more serious English bands, like Travis or Coldplay, that build huge followings abroad before their albums are released in the United States.
pair.h: Coldplay album tops the UK chart.

pair.t: HMV, Britain's largest music retailer, forecast that the album, released yesterday, would sell 200,000 copies in the first three days of issue. There are hopes that it will match the band's previous offering, X&Y, and sell between 300,000 and 400,000 in the first week and sail comfortably to No 1.
pair.h: Coldplay album tops the UK chart.

pair.t: Coldplay have entered the charts at number one with new album Viva La Vida Or Death And All His Friends. The album has sold 302,074 copies since its release on Thursday - enough to earn it a platinum award after just three days on sale. The band have now topped the UK charts with each of their first four studio albums.
pair.h: Coldplay album tops the UK chart.

pair.t: Japanese car manufacturer Honda has begun the first commercial production of a zero-emission, hydrogen fuel-cell powered vehicle. The four-seater, called FCX Clarity, runs on electricity produced by combining hydrogen with oxygen, and emits water vapour.
pair.h: Honda makes hydrogen cars.

pair.t: Honda has begun the first commercial production ever of a hydrogen fuel cell-powered car. The Japanese auto manufacturer ceremoniously launched production of its first hydrogen-powered vehicles on Sunday in Tochigi, Japan, and announced its first customers.
pair.h: Honda makes hydrogen cars.

pair.t: There's been very rapid development in battery technology and range. If you add quick charging capability in the future, there'd be little objection to electric, especially compared to the huge infrastructure you'd need for hydrogen. Car manufacturer Honda has already switched away from the hydrogen concept to an electric one.
pair.h: Honda makes hydrogen cars.

pair.t: Fashion chain Primark has axed three longstanding suppliers in southern India for using child labour after being alerted to the practice by the BBC.
pair.h: Primark fires child worker firms.

pair.t: Garment workers for factories owned by exporters who supply to Gap, Matalan and Primark, told the Guardian they were paid similar wages and regularly forced to work overtime of between six and 18 hours per week.
pair.h: Primark fires child worker firms.

pair.t: Inflation in the eurozone has a climbed to a record level amid higher food and fuel costs, official figures show. The annual rate of inflation in the 15 state zone hit 3.7% in May, according to the Eurostat statistical office.
pair.h: Euro inflation is at record high.

pair.t: Surging food and fuel prices drove euro zone inflation to a new record high of 3.7 per cent year-on-year in May, data showed, likely cementing expectations that the European Central Bank will raise rates on July 3rd.
pair.h: Euro inflation is at record high.

pair.t: The European Central Bank kept interest rates at a six-year high yesterday to fight inflation even as the euro-region economy cools. ECB policymakers meeting in Frankfurt left the benchmark lending rate at 4 percent.
pair.h: Euro inflation is at record high.

pair.t: Inflation in the euro zone cooled in April to 3.3% from a record high of 3.6% in March, according to a first estimate today from the EU's Eurostat data agency. Private sector economists had expected inflation to ease in April to 3.4% after hitting the March peak, driven by soaring oil and food prices.
pair.h: Euro inflation is at record high.

pair.t: A man who murdered two people at a party with the same bullet has been jailed for a minimum of 20 years. Iain Davis, 27, of Brixton, south London, shot DJ Ashley Kenton, 22, in the neck in an argument at a 2002 New Year's party in Hackney, east London.
pair.h: A man was found guilty of killing partygoers.

pair.t: Netherlands play a revitalised Russia in Euro 2008's third quarter-final today, with a place in the last four against world champions Italy or Group D winners Spain the prize.
pair.h: Netherlands beat Russia in soccer.

pair.t: With record high petrol prices hitting motorists in their wallets, customers have apparently decided that small is beautiful and are selecting only the most diminutive models available from car showrooms.
pair.h: Ford will make fewer big cars.

pair.t: Car giant Ford has sold its luxury UK-based car brands Jaguar and Land Rover to Indian company Tata.
pair.h: Tata takes over Jaguar.

pair.t: Tata, the Indian conglomerate which claims to make the world's cheapest automobile, has emerged as the formal preferred bidder to buy Jaguar and Land Rover from US carmaker Ford.
pair.h: Tata takes over Jaguar.

pair.t: Increasing struggles by consumers and businesses to make payments on a variety of loans, not just mortgages, are setting off a new wave of trouble in the financial sector that is battering even institutions that had steered clear of the subprime-home-loan debacle.
pair.h: A new crisis is threatening financial institutions.

pair.t: A Macedonian journalist was arrested on suspicion of murdering at least three women and then reporting on the crimes himself, a police spokesman said Saturday. Vlado Taneski, 56, allegedly kidnapped, abused and raped the victims in the southwestern town of Kicevo, before cutting them into pieces and dumping them in various places in plastic bags, the spokesman Ivo Kotevski told Agence France-Presse.
pair.h: A journalist reports on his own murders.

pair.t: The days had turned into weeks since Ivan Safronov's corpse was recovered from the courtyard of his Moscow apartment building, but police investigators had not visited the offices of Kommersant, the independent business daily where Safronov had worked for a decade as military correspondent.
pair.h: A journalist reports on his own murders.

pair.t: A Chinese crested-chihuahua cross-breed dog is defending its title of world's ugliest dog. Two-year-old Elwood and his owner scooped $1,000 prize money in the 2007 competition.
pair.h: Elwood is the world's ugliest dog.

pair.t: A tiger cub rejected by her mother in a zoo in Russia has been adopted by a surrogate canine mother.
pair.h: A dog has adopted a tiger.

pair.t: A miniature Pinscher dog in Germany has adopted a baby tiger. The tiger, named Siera, was born at the end of December in a circus based in the town of Wülfrath. But her mother couldn't give her any milk so she had to be hand fed from a baby bottle.
pair.h: A dog has adopted a tiger.

pair.t: Saimai, a 6-year-old Bengal tiger, has nurtured groups of piglets since she was 2 years old. The piglets wear striped vests, similar to a tiger's coat.
pair.h: A dog has adopted a tiger.

pair.t: Nasa's Phoenix spacecraft unearths evidence of ice in the soil around its landing site on Mars.
pair.h: Ice was discovered on Mars.

pair.t: It was the promise of ice that brought Phoenix to the arctic plains of Mars. The mission was funded on the expectation that we would find ice.
pair.h: Ice was discovered on Mars.

pair.t: The existence of ice on Mars was confirmed today by NASA scientists, the first time frozen water has been sampled on another planet. Water in liquid form is an essential ingredient for life.
pair.h: Ice was discovered on Mars.

pair.t: Scientists claim they have cured advanced skin cancer for the first time using the patient's own cells cloned outside the body. The 52-year-old man involved was free of melanoma two years after treatment.
pair.h: Cloned cells were used to cure cancer.

pair.t: New research from Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC), Cornell University, and The University of Connecticut describes a novel way of producing therapeutic nerve cells that can cure mice with Parkinson's-like disease.
pair.h: Cloned cells were used to cure cancer.

pair.t: Air travel of all kinds has increased, including private corporate jets and freight flights carrying fruit to markets all over the world. But the growth in passengers on European low-cost airlines has been phenomenal, almost doubling to 120 million per year in 2007 from about 60 million per year in 2005, according to the European Low Fares Airline Association.
pair.h: Air travel increases in Europe.

pair.t: Every now and then for the heck of it, I scan air fare prices to Europe with the usual carriers. This morning, 05/23, I scanned again and got one hell of a shock when I saw the increase in fares.
pair.h: Air travel increases in Europe.

pair.t: Starting today, the so-called open-skies agreement goes into effect, allowing airlines based in the United States and Europe to fly across the Atlantic between any two airports in each region.
pair.h: Air travel increases in Europe.

pair.t: Felipe Massa of Ferrari has won Formula One's French Grand Prix. Massa overtook teammate and pole sitter Kimi Raikkonen with 32 laps to go Sunday and held on for a 17.9-second victory. It is the second consecutive Ferrari sweep at the Circuit de Nevers.
pair.h: Massa wins the French Grand Prix.

pair.t: The Brazilian profited after Kimi Raikkonen, his Ferrari team-mate, ran into problems with a broken exhaust. Raikkonen was in control for much of the race before his right-hand exhaust cracked at half-distance, allowing Massa to come through.
pair.h: Massa wins the French Grand Prix.

pair.t: The world's first moving building, a 80-storey tower with revolving floors giving an shifting shape, will be built in Dubai, its architect says. The Dynamic Tower design is made up of 80 pre-fabricated apartments which will spin independently of one another.
pair.h: Dubai plans a shapeshifting skyscraper.

pair.t: The Da Vinci Tower (also known as Dynamic Architecture Building) is a proposed 313 m (1,027 ft), 68-floor tower in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. The tower is expected to be architecturally innovative for several reasons. Uniquely, each floor will be able to rotate independently. This will result in a constantly changing shape of the tower.
pair.h: Dubai plans a shapeshifting skyscraper.

pair.t: An unfinished skyscraper in the Gulf state of Dubai has become the world's tallest building, at 141 storeys, its developers say. Emaar Properties said the 512m (1,680ft) Burj Dubai is now taller than Taiwan's 508m (1,667ft) Taipei 101.
pair.h: Dubai plans a shapeshifting skyscraper.

pair.t: I think that the Infinity Tower reflects the boundless money and ever-burgeoning profits of foreign contractors as they reap the seemingly never-ending petro-dollars of Dubai and its neighbors' ruling families.
pair.h: Dubai plans a shapeshifting skyscraper.

pair.t: Italy's Senate has passed legislation which opponents of PM Silvio Berlusconi say is designed to help him in his legal battles with the nation's courts.
pair.h: The Berlusconi bill is passed in Italy.

pair.t: The Parliament dealt Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi an unexpected setback that suggested dissent within the ranks of his governing coalition. Voting in a secret ballot, the lawmakers blocked passage of a fiercely contested bill that would consolidate Mr. Berlusconi's ownership of much of the news media and which critics say would give him too much influence.
pair.h: The Berlusconi bill is passed in Italy.

pair.t: Silvio Berlusconi, the Italian premier, was heckled in parliament yesterday as he defended the heavy-handed response to the protests at the G8 summit in Genoa.
pair.h: The Berlusconi bill is passed in Italy.

pair.t: A Kent dock worker is being treated for serious injuries after a tonne of potatoes fell on him. The alarm was raised at 0930 BST after the 65-year-old man became trapped in the cargo hold of a ship at Sheerness docks as the cargo was being unloaded.
pair.h: A man was crushed by potatoes.

pair.t: A Sheerness dock worker has been flown to hospital with serious injuries after a one-ton sack of potatoes fell on top of him, Yourswale reports.
pair.h: A man was crushed by potatoes.

pair.t: A man was killed after his car collided with a large cow, sending the creature flying into the air before it landed on the car rooftop and crushed the driver.
pair.h: A man was crushed by potatoes.

pair.t: U.S. immigration authorities denied the visa because George, 48, faces trial in November in London on charges of false imprisonment relating to an April 2007 incident, according to a statement from Boy George's management, posted on his site.
pair.h: Boy George is denied an entry visa.

pair.t: The singer had said he wanted to repay the kindness he received two years ago from sanitation employees, when he swept Big Apple streets for five days as court-ordered community service.
pair.h: Boy George is denied an entry visa.

pair.t: Laws banning age discrimination in workplace came into effect on 1 October 2006, with amendments scheduled to come into force on 1 December 2006. The new laws will outlaw age discrimination in terms of recruitment, promotion and training.
pair.h: Age discrimination is outlawed.

pair.t: A senior consultant in the care of older people, Dr Adrian Treloar, stated at the end of last year that elderly patients are being left to starve to death in NHS hospitals because of an unspoken policy of involuntary euthanasia designed to relieve pressure on the NHS (Laville and Hall, 1999).
pair.h: Age discrimination is outlawed.

pair.t: Moreover, Ms Hutchinson is wrong in her assertion that age discrimination has been outlawed. There are so many exceptions with the age regulations, that in many cases it is entirely legal: these exceptions affect 20% of the population, those over 65.
pair.h: Age discrimination is outlawed.

pair.t: The Pakistani military has launched an offensive against militants near the main north-western city of Peshawar, security officials said. Militants have become more active in and around Peshawar in recent months, say correspondents.
pair.h: The Pakistani army attacks militants.

pair.t: Pakistani forces bombarded suspected militant hideouts with mortar shells Saturday as the government launched a major offensive against Taliban fighters threatening the main city in the country's volatile northwest, officials said.
pair.h: The Pakistani army attacks militants.

pair.t: Peace talks between the Pakistani government and insurgents continued this week despite a series of violent attacks. Analysts and government officials say that the violence will not affect Islamabad's resolve to reach negotiated settlements with the rebels.
pair.h: The Pakistani army attacks militants.

pair.t: Hillary Clinton has joined Barack Obama at a rally - their first public event since she pulled out of the race to be the Democratic presidential candidate. The rally in Unity, New Hampshire, was an opportunity for supporters of the party to come together after the divisive primary battle.
